Another point: in Fortran, the .or. and .AND. logical operators have a certain precedence. For multiple ORs, since they are all ORs, the parentheses I added should group the terms correctly. Let me make sure.

In the Fortran if condition:

if ( (x ==5 .or. x ==7) .or. (a ==5 .or. a ==7) .or. (y ==5 .or. y ==7) ) then

Yes, this groups each variable's own conditions first (like (x is 5 or7)), then OR those together. So that is correct. The parentheses ensure that each variable's condition is evaluated together.

Now, another thing to note is integer values. In the Java code, the inputs are parsed as integers. So in Fortran, the input is read via read *, which expects integers. So as long as the input is three space-separated numbers, it should work.

Putting all together, the code becomes:

program atcoder_abc042_a

  implicit none

  integer :: x, a, y
  character(len=3) :: h = "NO"

  read *, x, a, y

  if ( (x ==5 .or. x ==7) .or. (a ==5 .or. a ==7) .or. (y ==5 .or. y ==7) ) then
      if (x + a + y == 17) then
          h = "YES"
      end if
  end if

  print *, trim(h)

end program atcoder_abc042_a

Thus, the final Fortran code would be:

program atcoder_abc042_a

  implicit none

  integer :: x, a, y
  character(len=3) :: h = "NO"

  read *, x, a, y

  if ( (x ==5 .or. x ==7) .or. (a ==5 .or. a ==7) .or. (y ==5 .or. y ==7) ) then
    if (x + a + y == 17) then
        h = "YES"
    end if
  end if

  print *, trim(h)

end program atcoder_abc042_a
